raw_text:
O'Sullivan keeps his powder dry
 
 When you are gunning for glory and ultimate success keeping the gunpowder dry is essential.
 
 Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan appears to have done that quite successfully in the run-up to this season's Six Nations Championship. He decreed after the 2003 World Cup that players should have a decent conditioning period during the year. That became a reality at the end of last summer with a 10-week period at the start of the this season. It may have annoyed his Scottish, and in particularly Welsh, cousins who huffed and puffed at the disrespect apparently shown to the Celtic League. We will say nothing of Mike Ruddock ''poaching'' eight of the Dragons side that faced Leinster on Sunday. But, like O'Sullivan, he was well within his rights, particularly when you are talking about the national side and pride that goes along with it. The IRFU has thrown their weight behind O'Sullivan, who must be glad that in the main, there is centrally-controlled contracts. Bar Keith Gleeson who is just returning from a broken leg, everyone of O'Sullivan's squad is fit, fresh and standing at the oche ready to launch this season's campaign.
 
 But I doubt whether O'Sullivan is going to gloat about the handling of his players. He is not that sort of person. However, he may look at the overworked and injury-hit England, Wales and France squads whose players have been overworked, and then pat himself on the back for his foresight. But there is still the question of turning up and transferring that freshness into positive results when the referee signals the start of the game. Already Ireland are being earmarked as hot favourites in many quarters to go the whole hog this season. A first Grand Slam since Karl Mullen's led the team to a clean sweep in 1948. With England and France visiting Lansdowne Road for the last time before the old darling is pulled down, everything looks perfectly placed. But in the days of yore that frightened the life out of any Irishman.
 
 Under the burden of great expectations, Ireland have crumpled. Take the Triple Crown-winning side of 1985 under Mick Doyle. They were expected to up the ante further for a Grand Slam, only the second in Ireland's history. What happened in 1986? Whitewashed. You see, Ireland, in any sport, love to be downsized. Then they can go out and prove a point to the contrary. It is the nature of the beast. But O'Sullivan's side are very capable of proving a salient point this season. After their first Triple Crown for 19 years, they can live up to their success and take a further step up the ladder. O'Sullivan has kept faith and displayed loyalty to his players, and they have repaid him in spades ... and there is more to come. He has some old dogs in his squad, but he will come to this season's championship with a different box of tricks, and a new verve to succeed. Ireland can indeed succeed, but just whisper it.
llama3.2:1b:
Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan keeps the gunpowder dry during intense preparation before the Six Nations Championship.

O'Sullivan has been praised for his foresight in allowing his players a conditioning period at the start of the season, which he believes is essential for success and maintaining freshness and motivation. 

The Irish team has undergone significant changes since their last Grand Slam victory in 1948, including the departure of some key players due to injury.

Despite high expectations, Ireland have struggled to perform under pressure, particularly against stronger teams such as England and France.
llama3.2:3b: Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan has successfully prepared his team for the Six Nations Championship by giving players a decent conditioning period. The IRFU supports O'Sullivan, who is unlikely to gloat about his handling of the squad. With England and France visiting Ireland, everything seems in place for success, but Ireland have a history of crumbling under pressure when expectations are high, such as after their 1985 Triple Crown win.
gemma2:2b: Eddie O'Sullivan planned for the Six Nations Championship by allowing players a conditioning period after the 2003 World Cup, giving him a strong team in good shape. His decision contrasts with other coaches who focused on domestic competitions,  and he's been praised by the IRFU for his foresight. Despite high expectations and potential to clinch the Grand Slam, O'Sullivan is cautious about overconfidence and acknowledges Ireland's past struggles against similar pressure. He believes this team can overcome historical challenges and achieve significant success in the upcoming championship, but there's also a silent reminder of previous disappointments.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan keeps his powder dry by ensuring players have adequate conditioning periods during the start of the season. He appears to be succeeding in keeping Ireland's national side under control despite pressure from other leagues like England and Wales. Despite criticism about overworked players, O'Sullivan is positive that he can turn around a struggling team with players who are fresh and ready to compete.
The review highlights Ireland's recent success in the Grand Slam, winning their first Triple Crown in 1985 under Mick Doyle, and discusses Ireland's potential for improvement this season. It suggests that O'Sullivan will continue to bring his side up to par despite expectations of a strong finish. The review focuses on Irish football's current state and the challenges ahead, with emphasis placed on the team's past success and O'Sullivan's continued loyalty to his players.
The reviewer also mentions that Ireland has some "old dogs" in their squad but plans to bring in new tricks and a new level of performance this season. They suggest that while Ireland is capable, they are just whispering about it as they continue the journey forward.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan maintains conditioning during the pre-season period despite opposition criticism. His team shows excellent fitness for the Six Nations Championship, leading favorites in the buildup towards this season's event. While there are concerns about England and France squads being overworked, Ireland remains a strong contender with great expectations.
qwen2.5:3b: Ireland coach Eddie O'S successfully kept his players' conditioning during the off-season. This has resulted in a fit and ready squad for the upcoming Six Nations Championship. O'Sullivan's decision is seen as wise by many due to England, Wales, and France teams facing overwork and injuries. Ireland are tipped as favorites to win this season, especially with their recent Triple Crown victory. However, O'Sullivan will need to translate his players' fitness into positive results during the games. Despite expectations, Ireland have shown they can deliver success, but only in whispers.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, let me tackle this query. The user wants a summary of a given text. They provided the original text and asked for a concise summary in plain text without any explanations or formatting.

First, I need to read through the entire text carefully to understand its main points. It seems to be about Eddie O'Sullivan, the coach at University College, his strategies during the Six Nations Championship, and his thoughts on player handling.

I notice that the user provided a detailed summary already. Now, they're asking for another concise version, so I should avoid that. My task is to create a short, clear summary from scratch while preserving key details and main ideas.

Let me break it down into sections: O'Sullivan's dry powder, his conditioning period during the season, the issue with his Scottish and Welsh cousins, Mike Ruddock's injury, Ireland's national success, and some commentary on his approach.

I should make sure each section is covered succinctly without losing essential information. Also, I need to keep it natural, avoiding any markdown or formatting as per their instructions.
</think>

Eddie O'Sullivan kept his powder dry during the Six Nations Championship run-up, emphasizing that conditioning was crucial for success. His practice period of 10 weeks at the start of the season, largely benefiting Celtic league players, was met with some criticism from his Scottish and Welsh cousins. O'Sullivan remains content with his players' efforts but has praised England, Wales, and France's injury-hit squads, suggesting he had foresight in managing their workload. Despite Ireland's recent struggles (triple crown winner won the last Grand Slam), they are now poised to succeed after 19 years.
tinyllama:1.1b: The author conveys the fact that Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan has decreed a 10-week period at the start of the season and performed well in preparing his squad for the upcoming round of games. The writer mentions the importance of maintaining physical condition before the Six Nations Championship, and how the national team and pride have been supported by the IRFU. The author also notes that O'Sullivan has not gloated over England's, Wales', and France's poor performances in previous years, but rather sees this season as a chance to turn up freshness into positive results. However, the writer notes that the upcoming matches against England, France, and Wales could potentially shape Ireland's future success.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
In response to the provided text:

Certainly! The statement provided discusses Eddie O'Sullivan's tactics for maintaining a high-performing team during this year's Six Nations Championship and his foresight in preparing the Irish players. 

The coach has successfully increased the team's conditioning period during the offseason, which allowed for a 10-week training camp prior to the championship. This process seems to have paid off as Ireland maintained their status as the favorites for this season's title. 

Barring any unforeseen circumstances, O'Sullivan's strategy is paying off and he will be expected to lead his team to victory against England, Wales, and France. Despite facing significant challenges in the form of overworked players and injuries, the Irish squad has managed to put together a strong performance on the field. 

In conclusion, O'Sullivan is not just a coach but also a strategist who has thought carefully about how to prepare his team for their upcoming matches. As the season progresses, we can expect to see the Ireland team putting in even more effort and focus than they have previously done.
phi:2.7b: Edward O'Sullivan's coaching strategy appears successful as evidenced by the impressive physical fitness of his players. However, the team has struggled in recent matches, particularly against England, Wales, and France. Despite this, O'Sullivan remains confident in his squad and believes they have what it takes to win the Grand Slam, which is their goal for the season.
orca-mini:3b: Eddie O'Sullivan keeps his powder dry when it comes to choosing players for the national side, decreed after the 2003 World Cup that they should have a decent conditioning period during the year. He has since decided to move away from this approach and instead, select players based on their current fitness level. This season's Six Nations Championship is a perfect example as Ireland's starting team is full of fit, fresh and ready to launch the campaign. However, O'Sullivan may still look at the overworked and injury-hit England, Wales, and France squads whose players have been overworked. He has also been earmarked as a hot favourite in many quarters to go the whole hog this season and achieve a Grand Slam, following the lifting of the last one in 1948. Ireland's last Triple Crown was achieved in 1985, and O'Sullivan's side has the potential to prove a salient point this season, but they will need to overcome their tendency to crumble under great expectations.
hermes3:3b: O'Sullivan keeps powder dry before Six Nations, preparing fit team ready for success & avoiding overworking players.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ireland coach Eddie O'Sullivan prioritized player conditioning, leading to a fit and fresh team going into the Six Nations Championship. Despite potential criticisms from Scottish and Welsh rivals, O'Sullivan's approach was within his rights as it concerned the national side and its pride. Ireland was already favored to win after their successful 2019 campaign, but faced challenges in turning their success into positive results against tough opponents like England, Wales, and France. The past had shown that Ireland could struggle under high expectations, but with a loyal team and O'Sullivan's continued faith in them, the future looked promising for Ireland to succeed this season.

O'Sullivan's loyalty to his players has been rewarded, and with a mix of experience and new strategies, Ireland have a real chance of success—though expectations should be tempered.

This approach contrasts with that of some Celtic League coaches who expressed disapproval due to perceived disrespect for their league's importance. Despite minor roster changes, O'Sullivan benefits from centralized contracts, leaving no player underperforming or injured.
